vulnerabilities.title: DLL Sideloading/Hijacking in Double Commander
vulnerabilities.description: Double Commander (v1.1.23 and prior) attempts to load certain DLLs (e.g., libheif.dll, librsvg.2-2.dll) from locations not securely bundled with the application. An attacker with write access to any directory in the system PATH may insert a malicious DLL to achieve arbitrary code execution. If the application is launched with administrative privileges, this can result in full system compromise. This vulnerability aligns with MITRE ATT&CK technique T1574.002: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Side-Loading and can be leveraged by adversaries post-exploitation to maintain persistence or escalate privileges.

disclosure_timeline.description: Vulnerability discovered and reported privately to Double Commander developers (alexx2000@mail.ru, rich2014.git@outlook.com, denis.bisson@denisbisson.org)
Alexander Koblov confirmed fix deployed in Double Commander 1.1.24
CVE ID requested from MITRE via cve-request@mitre.org
Parallel notification sent to CERT Polska
CERT.PL confirmed MITRE should handle as primary CNA per CVE assignment rules

vulnerabilities.vendor_response: Positive - Issue confirmed and fixed in version 1.1.24
vulnerabilities.proof_of_concept: A benign DLL executing calc.exe was placed in a user-writable PATH directory. Upon launching doublecmd.exe, the DLL was loaded and the payload executed, demonstrating successful DLL hijacking. Behavior consistent with MITRE ATT&CK T1574.002. Visual proof-of-concept documentation (dll-sideloading.png, calc.png) available upon request.
